topics.title: Probability

concepts.title: Probability Basics
concepts.definition: A number from 0 to 1 representing likelihood of an event.
concepts.plain_english: How likely something is to happen.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to quantify uncertainty and risk.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Independent vs Dependent Events.

examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Sample Space
concepts.definition: Set of all possible outcomes of a random process.
concepts.plain_english: All the outcomes that could happen.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when defining events and calculating probabilities.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Independent vs Dependent Events.

examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Events
concepts.definition: A subset of the sample space representing outcomes of interest.
concepts.plain_english: The outcome(s) you care about.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to formalize probability questions.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Independent vs Dependent Events.

concepts.title: Independent vs Dependent Events
concepts.definition: Independent events do not affect each other’s probabilities; dependent events do.
concepts.plain_english: Whether one thing changes the chance of another.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for risk calculations and conditional logic.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Independent vs Dependent Events.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Conditional Probability
concepts.definition: Probability of event A given event B occurred: P(A|B).
concepts.plain_english: Chance of A when you already know B is true.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for diagnostic reasoning and segmentation.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Conditional Probability.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Bayes’ Theorem
concepts.definition: Rule that updates beliefs using evidence: P(A|B)=P(B|A)P(A)/P(B).
concepts.plain_english: How you update what you believe after new evidence.
concepts.when_to_use: Use in diagnostic testing, prediction updates, and risk scoring.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Bayes’ Theorem.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Uniform Distribution
concepts.definition: Distribution where all outcomes in a range are equally likely.
concepts.plain_english: Everything in the range is equally likely.
concepts.when_to_use: Use as a simple baseline distribution.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to improve decisions and reduce uncertainty.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Binomial Distribution
concepts.definition: Distribution of number of successes in n independent Bernoulli trials with probability p.
concepts.plain_english: Counts how many successes out of n tries.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for yes/no outcomes across repeated trials.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to improve decisions and reduce uncertainty.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Poisson Distribution
concepts.definition: Distribution of counts of events in a fixed interval with a constant average rate.
concepts.plain_english: How many events happen in a time/window.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for arrivals, defects, or rare events counts.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to improve decisions and reduce uncertainty.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Normal Distribution
concepts.definition: Bell-shaped continuous distribution defined by mean and standard deviation.
concepts.plain_english: The classic bell curve.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when modeling many natural measurement processes or as an approximation via CLT.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to improve decisions and reduce uncertainty.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Exponential Distribution
concepts.definition: Continuous distribution of time between Poisson events; memoryless.
concepts.plain_english: Time between events when arrivals are random.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for inter-arrival times and waiting-time modeling.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to improve decisions and reduce uncertainty.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

topics.title: Sampling & Estimation

concepts.title: Sampling Methods
concepts.definition: Techniques to select a sample (random, stratified, cluster) to represent a population.
concepts.plain_english: How you choose what to measure.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to improve representativeness and reduce bias.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Central Limit Theorem (CLT).

examples.title: Sampling Methods micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Sampling Methods.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Sampling Bias
concepts.definition: Systematic difference between the sample and the population that distorts estimates.
concepts.plain_english: If you sample the wrong way, you learn the wrong thing.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to assess whether results generalize.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Central Limit Theorem (CLT).

examples.title: Sampling Bias micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Sampling Bias.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Sampling Distribution
concepts.definition: Distribution of a statistic (like the mean) over repeated samples from the population.
concepts.plain_english: How an estimate would vary if you repeated the sampling.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to understand uncertainty in estimates.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Central Limit Theorem (CLT).

examples.title: Sampling Distribution micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Sampling Distribution.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Central Limit Theorem (CLT)
concepts.definition: For large samples, the sampling distribution of the mean approaches normal, regardless of population shape (with conditions).
concepts.plain_english: Averages become bell-shaped when you sample enough.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to justify normal-based confidence intervals/tests.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: Central Limit Theorem (CLT) micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Central Limit Theorem (CLT).
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Point Estimates
concepts.definition: Single-number estimate of a population parameter (e.g., sample mean for population mean).
concepts.plain_english: Your best single guess of the true value.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when reporting a parameter estimate before adding uncertainty.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: Point Estimates micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Point Estimates.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Confidence Intervals
concepts.definition: Range of plausible values for a population parameter with a stated confidence level.
concepts.plain_english: A likely range for the true value.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to quantify uncertainty around estimates.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: Confidence Intervals micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Confidence Intervals.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: CI for Mean
concepts.definition: Confidence interval estimating a population mean, typically using t-distribution when σ is unknown.
concepts.plain_english: Range where the true average likely falls.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when estimating average outcomes with uncertainty.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: CI for Mean micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: CI for Mean.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: CI for Proportion
concepts.definition: Confidence interval estimating a population proportion (rate).
concepts.plain_english: Range for the true rate (e.g., error rate).
concepts.when_to_use: Use for rates like defect %, readmission %, compliance %.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: CI for Proportion micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: CI for Proportion.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Sample Size Planning
concepts.definition: Process of selecting n to achieve desired precision or power given variability and effect size.
concepts.plain_english: How many data points you need to trust the result.
concepts.when_to_use: Use before experiments or studies to avoid underpowered decisions.
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

topics.description: Draw population conclusions from samples using sampling distributions and confidence intervals.

topics.title: Hypothesis Testing

concepts.title: Null vs Alternative Hypothesis
concepts.definition: Null hypothesis represents no effect; alternative represents a meaningful effect or difference.
concepts.plain_english: The default assumption vs what you're trying to prove.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to frame statistical tests clearly.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Type I Error.
Often learned alongside Type II Error.

examples.title: Null vs Alternative Hypothesis micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Null vs Alternative Hypothesis.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e (Hypothesis Testing)
resources.description: Hypothesis tests (t, chi-square, ANOVA) with worked examples.

concepts.title: Type I Error
concepts.definition: Rejecting a true null hypothesis (false positive).
concepts.plain_english: Calling a change real when it isn’t.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to weigh the cost of false alarms.
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Null vs Alternative Hypothesis.
Often learned alongside Type II Error.
Helps explain how to interpret the downstream concept.

resources.description: Hypothesis tests (t, chi-square, ANOVA) with worked examples.

concepts.title: Type II Error
concepts.definition: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative).
concepts.plain_english: Missing a real change because you lacked evidence.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to weigh the cost of missed opportunities.
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Null vs Alternative Hypothesis.
Often learned alongside Type I Error.

concepts.title: Significance Level (α)
concepts.definition: Pre-chosen threshold for Type I error rate used to decide statistical significance.
concepts.plain_english: How strict you are about avoiding false alarms.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to set decision rules before running a test.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: p-value
concepts.definition: Probability of observing results at least as extreme as the data, assuming the null hypothesis is true.
concepts.plain_english: How surprising your result would be if nothing changed.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to quantify evidence against the null (with effect size and context).
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: Statistical Power
concepts.definition: Probability of correctly rejecting the null when the alternative is true (1−β).
concepts.plain_english: How likely you are to detect a real effect.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for study planning and interpreting null results.
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: Effect Size
concepts.definition: Magnitude of a difference or relationship, independent of sample size.
concepts.plain_english: How big the impact really is.
concepts.when_to_use: Use alongside p-values to judge practical importance.
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: Multiple Testing
concepts.definition: Testing many hypotheses increases the chance of false positives unless adjusted.
concepts.plain_english: If you test lots of things, some look 'significant' by luck.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when exploring many variables or segments.
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?
concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.

concepts.title: Bonferroni Correction
concepts.definition: Adjustment that controls family-wise error by using α/m for m tests.
concepts.plain_english: A stricter threshold when you run many tests.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when false positives are very costly.
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Null vs Alternative Hypothesis.

resources.description: Hypothesis tests (t, chi-square, ANOVA) with worked examples.

concepts.title: False Discovery Rate (FDR)
concepts.definition: Expected proportion of false positives among rejected hypotheses.
concepts.plain_english: How many 'discoveries' might be wrong.
concepts.when_to_use: Use in high-dimensional testing where you want balance between discovery and caution.
concepts.improvement_goal: Make better decisions by separating real effects from random noise.
diagnostic_questions: Is the effect size meaningful operationally?
Are assumptions and data quality acceptable?
How many hypotheses are being tested?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.title: Z-test
concepts.definition: Test comparing a mean/proportion to a known value using normal distribution assumptions (often large n).
concepts.plain_english: A test when sample size is big and variability is known/approximated.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for proportions and large-sample mean testing.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance

concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

Often learned alongside Type I Error.
Often learned alongside Type II Error.

examples.title: Z-test micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Z-test.

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e (Hypothesis Testing)
resources.description: Hypothesis tests (t, chi-square, ANOVA) with worked examples.

concepts.title: One-sample t-test
concepts.definition: Test whether a sample mean differs from a hypothesized value using t-distribution.
concepts.plain_english: Checks if your average is different from a target.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for mean comparisons when σ is unknown.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Observations are independent.; Data are approximately normal (or sample size is large).
concepts.limitations: Sensitive to outliers and strong skew.; Statistical significance may not mean practical importance.

links.note: Often learned alongside Null vs Alternative Hypothesis.
Often learned alongside Type I Error.
Often learned alongside Type II Error.

examples.title: One-sample t-test example
examples.scenario: You compare two groups to see whether their averages differ.
examples.solution: Run the appropriate t-test; interpret p-value and confidence interval; if meaningful, implement change and monitor.

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e (Hypothesis Testing)

concepts.title: Two-sample t-test
concepts.definition: Test whether two independent group means differ (with equal/unequal variance variants).
concepts.plain_english: Checks if two groups have different averages.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for group comparisons like before/after (independent samples).
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Observations are independent.; Data are approximately normal (or sample size is large).
concepts.limitations: Sensitive to outliers and strong skew.; Statistical significance may not mean practical importance.

Often learned alongside Type I Error.

examples.scenario: You compare two groups to see whether their averages differ.

concepts.title: Paired t-test
concepts.definition: Test of mean difference for paired observations (same unit measured twice).
concepts.plain_english: Checks if individuals changed over time.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for before/after on the same subjects.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Observations are independent.; Data are approximately normal (or sample size is large).
concepts.limitations: Sensitive to outliers and strong skew.; Statistical significance may not mean practical importance.

links.note: Often learned alongside Null vs Alternative Hypothesis.
Often learned alongside Type I Error.
Often learned alongside Type II Error.

examples.scenario: You compare two groups to see whether their averages differ.
examples.solution: Run the appropriate t-test; interpret p-value and confidence interval; if meaningful, implement change and monitor.

concepts.title: Chi-Square Test
concepts.definition: Test of association between categorical variables using contingency tables.
concepts.plain_english: Checks if categories are related.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for independence tests on counts (e.g., outcome by group).
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Null vs Alternative Hypothesis.
Often learned alongside Type I Error.
Often learned alongside Type II Error.

concepts.title: Fisher’s Exact Test
concepts.definition: Exact test for association in small-sample contingency tables.
concepts.plain_english: A chi-square alternative when counts are small.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when expected cell counts are low.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Observations are independent.; Data are approximately normal (or sample size is large).
concepts.limitations: Sensitive to outliers and strong skew.; Statistical significance may not mean practical importance.

Often learned alongside Type I Error.

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e (Hypothesis Testing)
resources.description: Hypothesis tests (t, chi-square, ANOVA) with worked examples.

concepts.title: One-way ANOVA
concepts.definition: Test whether three or more group means differ by comparing between-group to within-group variation.
concepts.plain_english: Checks if at least one group mean is different.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for comparing averages across multiple groups.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this test to validate whether a change is real.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Statistical significance alone is not practical significance

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Independent observations.; Normally distributed residuals.; Equal variances across groups.
concepts.limitations: Sensitive to unequal variances and non-normality.; Post-hoc comparisons must be adjusted to control false positives.

links.note: Often learned alongside Null vs Alternative Hypothesis.
Often learned alongside Type I Error.
Often learned alongside Type II Error.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: One-way ANOVA.

resources.description: Hypothesis tests (t, chi-square, ANOVA) with worked examples.

concepts.title: Post-hoc Tests
concepts.definition: Follow-up comparisons after ANOVA to identify which groups differ while controlling error rates.
concepts.plain_english: Finds which groups differ after you know a difference exists.
concepts.when_to_use: Use after ANOVA when you need pairwise differences.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?
concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.
